div.head: Typology (Local)
div.p: Mainly rural dialects with many peculiar lexical developments

div.head: General
div.p: Tihama is the name of the narrow coastal strip along the Red Sea stretching from the Gulf of Aqaba in the north to Bab al-Mandab in the south. This entry only deals with the dialects spoken in the Yemeni part of the Tihama, particularly with its central part from al-Hudayda to Mocha.

div.head: Research history
div.p: Though first remarks on the vocabulary were already provided by Carsten Niebuhr (1772) (pp. 85-88), the dialects of the Yemeni Tihama have not been studied in detail yet. Some information is found in Rossi (1938a) (pp. 263-265) and Rossi (1938b) (pp. 464-469). Diem (1973) has a short chapter (pp. 65-70) on the Tihama and summarizes also previous studies. A few phonological and morphological features are analysed in Greenman (1979). Simeone-Senelle et al. (1994) present a good overview of the most important grammatical features including remarks on the lexicon. Simeone-Senelle (1995) focuses on verbs of motion, Simeone-Senelle (1996) on negation. A collection of seven short texts from the dialects of two villages (as-Suwayq and aš-Šiǧān, both near Zabīd) is found in Behnstedt (1996). The same author’s Dialect Atlas of North Yemen and adjacent Areas (2017) (based on the first edition 1985) also provides information on lexical and grammatical features of several dialects spoken in the Tihama.

div.head: Dictionaries
div.p: Vocabulary related to the Tihama is found in Peter Behnstedt’s Glossar (1992-2006), Piamenta (1990-1991), and Simeone-Senelle et al. (1994) (pp. 225-228).
